awd_titl_txt: Workforce Preparation through Computing Scholarship (We-Prep-CS) Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The Department of Computer Science at Hampton University is creating the Workforce Preparation through Computing Scholarship (We-Prep-CS) Program.  It will support up to 20 undergraduate students and up to 18 graduate students.  Each student will be awarded up to $10,000 per year based on their financial need.  We-Prep-CS will be part of Hampton University's continuing efforts to enhance undergraduate education and research in computer science as well as to increase the number of women and African-Americans who pursue advanced degrees and careers in computing.  These additional technical workers will help increase the nation's economic competitiveness.  

The Department of Computer Science at Hampton University has a legacy of contributing to the diversity of the computer science workforce and works closely with a number of industry, academic, and government partners. The proposed project adds to the comprehensive student support services within the department and supports efforts by the Graduate College to ensure the success of students seeking master's degrees in computer science. Scholarships will enable undergraduate and graduate students in computing programs to study full-time, while project activities will engage students academically and socially by providing research and internship opportunities, social cohort building activities, career counseling, and graduate school and workforce preparation. The project will demonstrate a creative, sustainable model for recruiting, engaging, retaining, and graduating historically underrepresented students in computing programs that can guide other institutions in efforts to diversify the STEM workforce. Student support activities developed through the proposed project will be sustainable and scalable, and an integrated evaluation plan will identify which activities should be expanded to meet the needs of all HU Computer Science majors in the future. The project will contribute to the scholarly understanding of STEM student perceptions of financial aid and need.  Best practices in preparation, recruitment, retention and engagement strategies will be made available to other institutions via publications, conferences, and workshops.  This will assist them with their efforts to broaden participation and to facilitate the progression of students through the pipeline from undergraduate through graduate degree programs in computing majors and/or into technical areas of national need. Data from this project will be collected through extensive evaluation processes and disseminated among the academic and workforce communities, organizations, and conference attendees.

por.por_cntn:
The Department of Computer Science at Hampton University received the S-STEM?s Workforce Preparation through Computing Scholarship (We-Prep-CS) Program to enhance undergraduate education and research in Computer Science as well as to increase the number of women and African Americans who pursue advanced degrees and careers in computing.  The goal of the program was to support academically talented, financially needed students to pursue a degree in computing (Computer Science, Computer Information Systems, or Cyber Security - Computer Science track) at Hampton University. In addition, the program engaged students academically and socially by providing research and internship opportunities, social cohort-building activities, career counseling, and graduate school and/or workforce preparation. 

During the 6-year We-Prep-CS program, we supported 31 students across 5 cohorts (3 undergraduate cohorts, 1 graduate cohort, and 1 special cohort during COVID-19): 1 graduate student (Male), 30 undergraduate (13 Female, 17 Male). Of 31 students, 4 had transferred out and graduated, 2 of which were in the computing field. The remaining 27 We-Prep-CS scholars remained at Hampton University; 16 students graduated in their respective computing majors.  Of these 16, 4 scholars have continued to pursue their graduate degrees and 12 have full-time employment.  Our We-Prep-CS scholars completed at least one summer internship by the time of their graduation.  Though not a requirement, 4 of the We-Prep-CS scholars conducted research, and 6 papers were accepted and presented at technical conferences.  Some We-Prep-CS scholars also had opportunities to participate in hackathons and/or technical competitions.

In addition to supporting students financially, the We-Prep-CS Program also offered peer-tutoring for the students who took the computer science gateway courses (CS1, CS2, and CS3 as well as Computer Architecture) including We-Prep-CS scholars and other students in Computer Science, Computer Engineering, and Mathematics.  Our We-Prep-CS scholars volunteered in various on-campus activities (prior to COVID-19): Hampton University High-School Day (annually, first Friday of April), Hampton University Admit Day / Open-House (annually, during Fall semester), Hampton University the Conference on the Black Family (2017), School of Science Research Day Symposium (2018),  Verizon Innovative Learning program for middle school male students (3 Saturdays during Spring 2017, 3 Saturdays during Fall 2017 and 3 Saturdays during Spring 2018), Technical Interview Preparation sessions for freshmen (2020) and other local community services as a part of ACM Student Chapter at Hampton University.   


Last Modified: 01/01/2022
Modified by: Chutima Boonthum
